column4: fred90-> are you in same directory where your source code is?  do a pwd to check
uuser-> i am not 100% sure, but since you have the mobo, try and install ubuntu to test it?
uuser-> oh well, sounds been a difficult bug to fix in linux, no straight answers
_Oz_-> ummm damn small linux works with 50meg hd and 64meg of ram
fred90-> then cd to your Documents directory and do the compiling there
ashok-> some are made in china, some are from india? same instructions you think?
ashok-> sometimes one has to take some risk, make your life more interesting
Lettuc3-> what is the problem? did it boot or not? if it booted, congrats
it booted, im just wondering why the kernel time counter just changed in the middle of booting up.
i asked a question, if you can answer, fine, if not, what concern of yours is it why i asked the question?
i know it's irrelevant, i want to understand _why_ it's behaving like that.
apologies for earlier. i admit i was getting a little worked for nothing.
i did have a look there, and there are no files that hold that information.
wait a minute. i think there is, wasn't checking as root.

ok, i have found the files in /var/spool/cups. i had previously been looking under cups-pdf instead, that's why i hadnt found them. i could manually delete those, each time, as root, but that's not terribly nice. is there another way to delete _completed_ print jobs as the user that did them, or will those files get rotated and eventually disappear, say after... x number of days, a week or something?

hmm. ah well, i guess i could make a bootup script that would take care of that... thanks anyway. at least now i know where they are (had somewhat assumed they would be listed under the cups-pdf printer, which is what i'd used). laters.
